questiontext.text:
A bat hits a stationary ball with a typical collision time of 2 ms. A speed of 51 m/s is imparted to the ball, which has a mass of 0.208 kg.

What impulse is applied to the ball?

{1:NUMERICAL:=10.6:0.21216#Good job!!~*#Incorrect, try again} N.s




What is the average force, $$F$$, exerted by the bat on the ball?

{1:NUMERICAL:=5304:106.08#Good job!!~*#Incorrect, try again} N

(Please give your answers correct to 1.d.p.)

(Question ID #1).

generalfeedback.text:
Recall from your lectures that impulse is equal to the product of force and time:

$$I=F.t$$

But according to Newton's second law:

$$F=m.a$$

Therefore:

$$I=F.t=m.a.t=m.\frac{\Delta v}{t}.t=m.\Delta v=10.6N.s$$,

as impulse is also equal to change in momentum.


Our original defintion of impulse as given above can be rearranged:

$$F=\frac{I}{t}=5304N$$.

---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Image adapted from 'http://www.spiritsd.ca/curr_content/physics30/opt_kindyn/images/bat2.gif'

hint.text:
HINT

Remember that impulse is equal to change in momentum.

Newton's second law of motion may also be helpful in answering this question.

generalfeedback.text:
Recall from your lectures that impulse is equal to the product of force and time:

$$I=F.t$$

But according to Newton's second law:

$$F=m.a$$

Therefore:

$$I=F.t=m.a.t=m.\frac{\Delta v}{t}.t=m.\Delta v=5.5N.s$$,

as impulse is also equal to change in momentum.


Our original defintion of impulse as given above can be rearranged:

$$F=\frac{I}{t}=2750N$$.

Remember that impulse is equal to change in momentum.

Newton's second law of motion may also be helpful in answering this question.

questiontext.text:
A bat hits a stationary ball with a typical collision time of 2 ms. A speed of 46 m/s is imparted to the ball, which has a mass of 0.184 kg.

What impulse is applied to the ball?

{1:NUMERICAL:=8.5:0.16928#Good job!!~*#Incorrect, try again} N.s




What is the average force, $$F$$, exerted by the bat on the ball?

{1:NUMERICAL:=4232:84.64#Good job!!~*#Incorrect, try again} N

(Please give your answers correct to 1.d.p.)

(Question ID #65).

generalfeedback.text:
Recall from your lectures that impulse is equal to the product of force and time:

$$I=F.t$$

But according to Newton's second law:

$$F=m.a$$

Therefore:

$$I=F.t=m.a.t=m.\frac{\Delta v}{t}.t=m.\Delta v=8.5N.s$$,

as impulse is also equal to change in momentum.


Our original defintion of impulse as given above can be rearranged:

$$F=\frac{I}{t}=4232N$$.

{1:NUMERICAL:=9.8:0.19522#Good job!!~*#Incorrect, try again} N.s




What is the average force, $$F$$, exerted by the bat on the ball?

{1:NUMERICAL:=4880.5:97.61#Good job!!~*#Incorrect, try again} N

(Please give your answers correct to 1.d.p.)

(Question ID #86).

generalfeedback.text:
Recall from your lectures that impulse is equal to the product of force and time:

$$I=F.t$$

But according to Newton's second law:

$$F=m.a$$

Therefore:

$$I=F.t=m.a.t=m.\frac{\Delta v}{t}.t=m.\Delta v=9.8N.s$$,

as impulse is also equal to change in momentum.


Our original defintion of impulse as given above can be rearranged:

$$F=\frac{I}{t}=4880.5N$$.
